intro: Phoradendron holoxanthum, commonly known as the golden mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that grows on the branches of various host trees. It is native to the southeastern United States and parts of Central America, where it thrives in humid, tropical climates. The plant has small, leathery leaves and produces yellowish-white flowers that bloom in the spring. Its berries are orange-red and contain seeds that are dispersed by birds. The botanical features of Phoradendron holoxanthum make it an important part of the ecological interactions in its native habitat.
